item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Omer_, post:1, topic:444240”]There are some things you need to fix.
First, add a switch statement (if you’re doing it the way you did it, I did it differently)
You also need to invoke ‘println’, not ‘printIn’. Finally, use " if you want quotations within strings.
Use the Scanner class in the java.util package to read from input, like this:

Check to see if the user wants to go to the next page like this:

if (new Scanner(System.in).nextLine().equals("yes"))
    // next page

Here’s a test sample.

[code=java]
import java.util.Scanner;

public class JavaBook {
public static void main(String[] args) {
String[] pages = {
“Test Book\nBy Darrel!”,
“Page 1: The eyes of the young boy opened, he didn’t know where he was, or what has happened, all he knows is\nthat he needs to find his friends.”,
“Page 2: “Where are they?!” he screamed. That’s when it all came back to him.\nThe Nyzerats kidnapped him!” };

	for (String string : pages) {
		System.out.println(string);
		System.out.println("\nNext page?");
		if (new Scanner(System.in).nextLine().equalsIgnoreCase("yes"))
			continue;
		else
			return;
	}
}

}
[/code][/quote]
creating a new instance of scanner for every page, nice

[quote=“Level 120 Dungeoneering, post:3, topic:444228”][quote author=t4 link=topic=546919.msg4009483#msg4009483 date=1339016220]
you should have an array of strings, each index is a page and each string is the contents. you can use something like scanner’s nextInt() and hasNextInt() to get the next page number from the user - you could also treat page 0 as the ‘next’ page and all you’d do is subtract 1 from the non-0 input to get the index in the array of pages.
[/quote]
Can you please tell me how to do that? I’m sorry, I’m a beginner. :)[/quote]
google is your friend, plus i only mentioned two concepts: arrays and the java.util.Scanner class.
